Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2010 08:43PM Issymom wrote: Don't spend time googling Breast Cancer as most likely it will not be cancer.  If, unfortunately, it is you will have the information from the pathology report to base your research on.  There are so many different facets to breast cancer that play into treatment, etc... that it is not a good idea to worry about something that may not apply to you. I found the biopsy interesting (I didn't feel a thing).  It was an Ultasound guided biopsy so I got to watch the entire thing.  I asked most of my questions after he was done.  He also showed me the samples which helped me understand what was really going on inside.  They won't tell you much and shouldn't because they really can't tell.  Good luck and hope you don't have to become a full fledged member of this group.  By the way, you are fortunate to be able to get your results back in 2 days.  The waiting is the worst thing.

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2010 07:59PM Issymom wrote: I had a bi-lat mastectomy in early December.  I was diagnosed with Triple Negative BC and then found out I was BRCA1+.  Didn't want to go through this again.  The surgery wasn't bad and I was driving, etc.. after 5 days.  I did delayed reconstruction as my BS and PS were adamant that I do them seperately.  This is different from what most people do but they are the top doctors in their field in Washington and so I trust them.  Manage one thing at a time. My sister (turning 40 in a month) found out last week that she is BRCA1+ as well.  Bummer.  She is definately having a hysterectomy but I think she will start with surveillance of the breast (assuming her first mammo/mri is OK - she hasn't had one yet).  Interestingly, I met with my BS today for a follow-up and I mentioned my sister and her decision.  He shocked me by saying that is not what he would do.  I was shocked because he is usually careful to say it is our decision, here are the facts.  I guess since she was not there and is not a patient he felt he could express his opinion.  I really appreciated his candidness.  The reason for his opinion is that recently, he has had 2 patients who are BRCA+ and have known it but did not prophylateclly remove their breast and now bone and/or lung mets.  He feels their Stage IV cancer was avoidable and just so sad.  At the end of our appointment he gave me a hug.  I was touched.  I will talk to my sister in a little while about his thoughts. Good luck to you Krista.  It will not be fun but it is so much better than Cancer.

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2010 09:05AM Issymom wrote: Anacortes Girl - We have chosen a hysterectomy over the oomph so that there is one less thing to go wrong with our bodies.  I spoke to a very good friend who is one the top Gyn in Seattle and that is her recommendation.  She said the risks of complications (prolapse....) is so little that this is what she would do herself (that says a lot to me).  My body is doing things I didn't expect so there will be one less thing to worry about.  It is a personal choice. Most people don't have complications doing both together but when the PS described how we are removing our own tissue which is traumatic and then putting in a foreign substance, I realized lots can go wrong.  Also, the reconstruction surgery (implants for me) is much less of a big deal.  I will be asleep and given a local nerve block instead of the general anesthetia.  Sounds better to me.
